title: Schedule OO flows
content:
This topic contains the instructions to schedule OO flows.

Overview

OO Scheduler allows you to control when to run your flows. You can specify a schedule to run for a specific flow and also set up recurring schedules for a task.

For example, to check for the number of servers that are online, define a flow to check the IP address and then create a schedule to run that flow.

View Scheduler

The Schedules are displayed in a table under the SCHEDULER tab. The display of schedules depends on the permissions assigned for your role. Contact your administrator for help with permissions.

  • If you your role has the View Schedules permission granted, then you'll be able to view the OO schedules and their details.
  • If you your role has the Manage Schedules permission granted, then you'll be able to view and edit schedules.

Scheduler actions

The schedules display in a table. Click on the column header in the table to sort the schedules by that column.

The menu bar has the following actions:

Action Description
Add Click to add a new schedule.
Edit

Select a schedule to edit.
Delete Select one or more schedules to delete.
Enable Select one or more disabled schedules to enable them.
Disable Select one or more schedules to disable them.
Refresh Click to refresh the schedules table.
Search Click to search by keywords.
Filter Click to filter schedules based on State, Next Run, and Previous Run. If no filters are added, click Add filter to add a filter.
Select columns

Click to select columns to display in the table. Select/deselect these columns: State, Schedule Name, Flow Name, Flow Identifier, Next Run, Previous Run, and User.

Create a schedule

Before you being, make sure you are logged in with a user account that's assigned a role with View schedules and Manage schedules permissions.

To create a schedule:

  1. On the SCHEDULER tab, click   in the menu bar to create a new schedule. A three step wizard to create a schedule appears requiring user inputs.
  2. In the default Select flow & settings step, click Flow Path drop-down to view the Flow Library tree. Expand the tree node and select the flow, or type the flow name in the search field to filter and click SELECT.
  3. In the Name box, you can customize the name of the schedule per your choice. The flow name get added by default, but you can use a different name, for example, if you have multiple schedules using the same flow.
  4. Select the Use empty value for prompts checkbox, if you want the schedule to skip over prompts for inputs. For any prompt that has no value assigned, it will use blank, and the scheduled flow will run without stopping to prompt for values. However, note that if any of these are required inputs, the flow will fail. If you don't select this checkbox, the run gets stopped and prompts for inputs, even if they're not required inputs.
  5. Click NEXT. Notice the Select flow & settings step gets check marked with success.
  6. On the Planning step, create a desired schedule plan, under the Start Date section, in the Select starting date box, click to open the calendar widget and then select the date and time for your schedule to start. The start time must be minimum 2 minutes later than the current time. The date and time defaults to the local timezone.
  7. Under the End date section, select:
    Never: Your schedule will run for ever.
    End after: Specify the number of occurrences after which the schedule ends. Default is 10 occurrences.
    End by: Click to open the calendar widget and then select the date and time for your schedule to end.
  8. In the Recurrence pattern section, select from one of the recurrence frequencies for the schedule: Minutely, Hourly, Daily, Weekly, Monthly, or Yearly.
  9. To run the flow on a minute basis, select Minutely and enter the duration. The value must be at least 1. For example, if you entered 5, the schedule will run once every 5 minutes.
  10. To run the flow on a hourly basis, select Hourly and enter the duration. The value must be at least 1. For example, if you entered 2, the schedule will run once every 2 hours.
  11. To run the flow on a daily basis, select Daily and Every day to run the flow once every day of the week. The flow run will start at the time set in the Start time field in the Range of recurrence section. Select Every weekday to run the flow once a day, on weekdays only. If the working week isn't Monday to Friday, use the Weekly option instead, and select the working days.
  12. To run the flow on a weekly basis, select Weekly and then select the days of the week on which you want the flow to run. If you select Weekly, you must select at least one day.
  13. To run the flow every month, select Monthly and select Day.
  14. To run the flow on a particular date in each month, select Day and select the date. For example, select 15 to run the flow on the fifteenth of every month.
  15. To run the flow once a month on a particular day of the week, select the day of the week, and whether it's the first, second, third, fourth, or last time that this day occurs in the month. For example, to run the schedule on the third Friday of each month, select third, then select Friday, and then select 1 month(s).
  16. To run the flow at intervals of several months, select a number of months. For example, to run a schedule once a quarter, on the first Monday of the quarter, select first, then select Monday, and then select 3 months.
    For example, in a schedule starting on April 1, 2022, and ending on December 20, 2022, with a recurrence pattern of the third day of every 2 months, the flow will run on June 3, August 3, October 3, and December 3.
  17. To run the flow on the last day of the month, select last and then select day instead of a specific day of the week.
  18. To run the flow once a year, select Yearly.
  19. To run the flow on a particular date each year, select Every and then select the month and the date. For example, every July 4.
  20. To run the flow once a year on a particular month and on a particular day of the week, select the month, then select the day of the week, and whether it's the first, second, third, fourth, or last time that this day occurs in the month. For example, the second Monday of each November.
  21. In the Exclusion pattern section, you can choose to exclude the flows from running on scheduled calendar owing to reasons such as downtime, maintenance, etc. You can save only one type of exclusion even if you add multiple types of exclusion. As the exclusion type selection is by radio buttons, the last active radio button/exclusion type is saved. You can choose from the following exclusion patterns.
  22. Date Time: Choose the date and the time on which you want to exclude the scheduled flow runs. For example, if you choose the Start time as 2022/03/28 20:00 and End time as 2022/03/29 20:30 and the click Add Exclusion, the scheduled flow won't run between 20:00 and 20:30 on the selected dates 2022/03/28 and 2022/03/29. It will however continue to run the flow on the originally set scheduled calendar. Use this exclusion for the scenarios such as downtime or maintenance.
  23. Date: Select the date on which you don't want to run the scheduled flow. For example, if you select the date 2022/03/28 and click Add Exclusion, the scheduled flow won't run on that selected date. Use this exclusion for the scenarios such as holidays or similar occasions.
  24. Time: Select the time on each day on which you don't want to run the scheduled flow. For example, if you select the time between 20:00 and 21:30 and then click Add Exclusion, the scheduled flow won't run on that selected times every day. Use this exclusion for the schedules set in minutes or hours every day.
  25. Click NEXT. Notice the Planning step gets check marked with success.
  26. On the Inputs step, configure the scheduled flow’s inputs or define custom ones.
  27. Specify the custom values for the existing flow input parameters. You can't delete the input parameters that are part of the flow.
  28. Add custom input parameters by clicking + ADD INPUT.
  29. In the Name box, you can customize the name of the parameter per your choice.
  30. In the Value box, specify the custom input value. Click the x icon that appears when you hover your mouse pointer on the Name or Value field to delete the custom input parameter.
    If the value you are entering is sensitive, for example a password, select the check box next to the lock icon to mask the value.
    Click the eye icon to toggle show and hide values.
  31. Add as many custom input parameters and specify value to them.
  32. Click FINISH. The schedule gets created and added to the schedules table under the SCHEDULER tab.

Edit a schedule

You can edit flow and settings, start date, end date, recurrence pattern, exclusion pattern, and custom values for the existing flow input parameters in a schedule.

To edit a schedule:

  1. On the SCHEDULER tab, select a schedule from the schedules table and click Edit icon in the menu bar. 
  2. In the Select flow & settings step, edit Flow Path and Name. 
  3. In the Planning step, Start Date section, edit the start date and time. By default, the start date automatically set to the next day.
    Click to open the calendar widget and then select the date and time for your schedule to start. The start time must be minimum 2 minutes later than the current time. The date and time defaults to the local timezone.
  4. In the End date section, edit the schedule end time.
  5. In the Recurrence pattern section, edit recurrence type and recurrence frequencies for the schedule.
  6. In the Exclusion pattern section, include or exclude the flows from running on scheduled calendar. Do note that warnings can appear on the past exclusions.
  7. In the Inputs step, edit the custom values for the existing flow input parameters.
